section_details.title: The Productivity Promise Nobody Has Verified
How We Got the Metrics Wrong
What Code Generation Actually Speeds Up
The Costs That Don't Show Up in Benchmarks
What the Most Effective Teams Do Differently

min_words_per_section.result: ALL PASS - smallest section is 716 words

min_links_per_section.result: ALL PASS - every section has 5+ inline links

min_examples_total.result: 17 named organizations with specific data points cited

prose_ratio_minimum.result: 100% prose - zero bullet points in the entire article

narrative_flow_check.result: Article follows hook -> context -> foundation -> deep-dive x3 -> analysis -> conclusion arc

header_style.result: All headers are conversational, no colons, 3-7 words

citation_style.result: All claims backed by inline links with contextual descriptions

strengths: Strong narrative tension between vendor claims and independent research
Specific data points with citations throughout (55% vs 19%, 39-point perception gap, 45% vulnerability rate, etc.)
17 named real-world organizations with specific deployments and measured outcomes
100% prose ratio - no bullet points, all flowing paragraphs
Balanced perspective presenting both benefits and costs with evidence
Actionable framework for engineering leaders in conclusion
key_studies_cited: METR 2025 RCT (16 developers, 246 tasks, 19% slower finding)
GitHub Copilot productivity study (95 developers, 55% faster)
Google internal RCT (21% faster, experience-dependent gains)
Stack Overflow 2025 Developer Survey (84% adoption, 29% trust)
Atlassian DevEx 2025 (3500 developers, 99% time savings with AI)
Palo Alto Networks/Sourcegraph (2000 devs, 25% avg productivity gain)
ZoomInfo Copilot study (400+ devs, 33% acceptance rate)
DORA 2024 (AI paradox: individual output up, delivery throughput down)
Cursor/technical debt study (806 repos, transient gains, persistent debt)
